bibl.title: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, April 24, 1921

div1.p: Hanson discusses a yellow fever outbreak on the frontier of Peru. He states that yellow fever cases are declining elsewhere.

div1.head: Letter from Henry Hanson to Wickliffe Rose, April 24, 1921
div1.opener:
COPY
Chiclayo, Peru,
April 24, 1921.
Mr. Wickliffe Rose, Field Manager,
International Health Board,
New York, N.Y.
My dear Mr. Rose:
div1.p:
I very much regret to report that I have just received
notice of the confirmation of a case of yellow fever in Trojillos,
in the Department to the south of us. Up to the present time I
have no further details in regard to where the case came from, or
whether there have been other cases. As you may have gathered from
my previous letters, and the copies of my reports to the Salubridad
in Lima, this has been my greatest worry but I had hoped that the
land quarantine would prevent the passage of people over the frontier.
It is a case of history repeating itself in regard to the reliability
of the Army in carrying out its orders, and a demonstration of their
incompetence.

This year however we are in a better condition than last
because we will have less stegomya and less opportunity for propa-
gation on account of the stegomya campaign which is well advanced
in the Department of Libertad. I shall leave for Libertad as soon
as a few indispensable details of the Central Office are settled.
Whether I change the location of the Central Office to Trojillos will
depend upon how I find conditions there upon arrival.

We have made an estimate of the number of cases and deaths
-2-
in this Department (Lambayeque) and we think conservatively, as
follows; 10,000 cases with 1,000 dead. In all parts of this
Department the epidemic is decreasing. I have just returned from
an inspection of the northern section, where it seems to be about
finished, practically all there have had it. I believe we can
stop it in Libertad because to the south of Libertad is an almost
impassable desert, which together with the active work, and greater
co-operation of the authorities there will offer hopes of better
results. I will send you more details later.
